Sounds good, @rhtyd - it should be pretty soon. I needed to mainly attend to other work over the past week or so, so I didn't have a chance to finalize what I was working on for VMware here (dynamic discovery). It should probably be ready early next week. Right now I am running my tests and making some final touch-up tweaks.

Packaging result: centos6 centos7 debian. JID-1386

I faced an issue today when vmware.create.full.clone is set to false, the code should read the config and allow resizing of root disk only when vmware.create.full.clone is true. Alternatively, the resize operation should not throw exception when disk length is > 1 but instead skip the resize operation.
@priyankparihar Can you please check and open a PR to address the issue reported by @rhtyd?

From the logs, it looks like the usage server was not started/usage entry was still not created for the volume when it was checked.  I will add a few more checks and may be little wait time to make sure that the usage server has executed before getting the entries from the database.

I will update the test case in 2-3 days.
Previous baseline tests to compare against: https://github.com/apache/cloudstack/pull/2217

@sateesh-chodapuneedi @priyankparihar see my fixes in #2211 I've made the code to skip when VM starts if the root disk chain length is > 1 logging a warning. I think we should not throw any exception during VM boots. I've also fixed the related marvin test.

@sateesh-chodapuneedi thanks for replying. I think for resizing to work, the first constraint is that at least the `vmware.create.full.snapshot` is set to `true`. How about this -- we throw an exception if this setting is true and diskchain length is > 1, and skip when this is false. As this is a storage pool scoped setting, we check the value in the root volume's (storage) pool id?
@rafaelweingartner thanks, no need to squash yourself. I'll squash merge using Github. I'll re-review the changes, and kick another round of tests.

LGTM
